Notes
Unable to delete old rational above.

This module is due to commence September 2025.

Due to Chemistry curriculum changes LIFE369 (taken exclusively by Year 4 Integrated MChem Medicinal Chemistry students) is now required to be Level 7 to ensure the students have the correct number of Level 7 credits in Year 4. LO's and subsequent assessment marking rubrics have been altered to reflect the change from Level 6 to Level 7. This change is necessary for 1 year (202526), ahead of the role out of the new BIOS modules.

Will appear in programme F1BF - Medicinal Chemistry with Pharmacology MChem. DEPP forms detailing changes to the programme have been submitted to School of Physical Sciences. This will appear in CM in due course.

Overview

Overview
This module will be delivered by a series of lectures and tutorials to provide an up-to-date understanding of CNS conditions, drugs that are used to treat those conditions, and how CNS drugs work at the cellular and molecular level.

The module will be delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Students will critically evaluate scientific literature and clinical data, synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex problems by applying appropriate knowledge, skills and creative thinking.

The module will be assessed by two summative exercises including data interpretation and analysis.
The prerequisite module is LIFE207 Principles of Pharmacology .
Educational Aims
To provide an explanation of the current understanding of drug treatment for common disorders of the brain.

To explain the latest knowledge of the pathophysiology of the brain, receptors and ion channels as drug targets, and the mechanisms of action of key classes of neuropharmacological agents.

To give students an awareness of the clinical effectiveness of neuropharmacological drugs.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The aim of this module is to provide an understanding of of drug treatment for common disorders of the brain. A further aim is to explain the molecular mechanism of action of key classes of neuropharmacological agents and the potential for side-effects and drug toxicity. Materials will be delivered through a series of lectures and tutorials. The module will be delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Students will critically evaluate scientific literature and clinical data, synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex problems by applying appropriate knowledge and skills. Problem solving, critical thinking, creativity will be utilised in analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions. The module will be assessed by two summative exercise. The module would be taken by students with a keen interest in neuropharmacology and medicinal chemistry.
Outline Syllabus
Lectures will split into three blocks and themed around neurotransmission in the nervous system, focusing on glutamate and GABA as neurotransmitters, treatments for depression, anxiety etc.   G-protein coupled receptors, structure activity relationships, their role in adrenergic neurotransmission.   Epilepsy, antiepileptic drug development, pharmacology of antiepileptic drugs.

Block, lecture title and theme:

Block 1: Drug targets at the synapse
Overview of neurotransmission in the CNS
Block 1: Drug targets at the synapse
Transporters at the synapse
Block 1: Drug targets at the synapse
Inhibitory neurotransmission; focus on GABAA receptor
Block 1: Drug targets at the synapse
Targets for the development of novel anti-depressants

Block 2: GPCRs
G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) systems
Block 2: GPCRs
Adrenoceptors: structure and function
Block 2: GPCRs
GPCR receptor theory and second messengers GPCRs
Block 2: GPCRs
GPCR diversification and desensitization

Block 3: Epilepsy
Epilepsy: clinical features and basic mechanisms
Block 3: Epilepsy
Pharmacology of traditional anti-epileptic drugs
Block 3: Epilepsy
Pharmacology of new anti-epileptic drugs
Block 3: Epilepsy
Alternative pharmacological and non-pharmacological treatments

This builds on the broader content covered in LIFE207 around understanding of the quantitative aspects of drug action, the relationship between drug efficacy and chemical structure, pharmacokinetics, drug concentration and response.

Library resources will be accessible through the module reading list, other key learning resources will accessible through VLE, Canvas. All journal articles are either Open Access or available as PDF's through Canvas.

Students are provided with reading material ahead of the lectures and are expected to read all resources on the reading list in order to complete the assessments and tutorials. Supplementary resources are encouraged for the assessments. Pre-tutorial material will be released in order to help them complete the tutorial.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching and learning method 1: Synchronous F2F lectures (13 x 1 hr lectures) to include polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc.

Teaching and learning method 2: Online asynchronous tutorial (2 x 1 hr) - These will take place at suitable points after delivery of the relevant F2F material and before the relevant assessments.

Teaching and learning method 3 (60 hrs): Self-directed learning aided by directed reading and formative questions on neuropharmacology. A list of reading material, from scientific papers to book chapters, will be provided for students at the end of each lecture to support their learning and progression through the course.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework: This module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students access the core attributes and hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. For example:

-Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. Students will receive formative feedback, both verbally and written, through the formative tutorials.

-Research-connected teaching: inclusion of clinical case studies allows incorporation of relevant, recent research. The module is delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence.

-Active learning: All lecture sessions aim to incorporate some element of active learning through short periods of tutor-led discussion, peer discussion, problem solving, polling etc.

-Confidence: students will learn to be able to adapt and apply their knowledge in new contexts through tutorial-based activities.
-Digital fluency: throughput the module students will think critically about the information they find and use, developing their ability to use digital platforms to problem-solve, create, collaborate, and communicate.

- Global citizenship: the module increases awareness of global disease burden and global drug development initiatives and students' potential future roles within these areas.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students will interpret scientific data and complete a written assessment that combines problem solving with synthesis of research-led materials.

Assessment cycle-I will be a 1000 word written assignment that involves data interpretation/essay focused on Drug targets at the synapse and GPCR's. This will be worth 40% and occur following the first cycle of teaching in week 6 to 8.

Assessment cycle-II will be a 1500 word written assignment that involves data interpretation/essay focused on Epilepsy. This will be worth 60% and occur at the end of the course in week 11 to 13 in May.

Feedback from Cycle 1 is received within 3 weeks so relevant feedback on structure, referencing and formatting etc can be applied to Cycle 2. Detailed feedback is released through Speedgrader on Canvas.

Reassessment strategy: there is a resit opportunity. The format of the assessments will be very similar but different questions will be employed. This will take place in the normal reassessment window and be capped at 50%. The resit in the summer covers both cycle I and cycle II. Failure of cycle I assessment does not impact ability to sit the cycle II assessment as different content is involved. The standard CoPA penalty for late submission applies.

Assessment is anonymous and submitted through Canvas the VLE which allows anonymous submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Prior LIFE modules in earlier years prepare students for the submissions therefore no draft opportunity is given, as is standard through all LIFE cycled assessments. Following assessment release they have 1 week to ask any questions relating to the assessment.

Notes
Unable to delete old rational above.

This module is due to commence September 2025.

Due to Chemistry curriculum changes LIFE369 (taken exclusively by Year 4 Integrated MChem Medicinal Chemistry students) is now required to be Level 7 to ensure the students have the correct number of Level 7 credits in Year 4. LO's and subsequent assessment marking rubrics have been altered to reflect the change from Level 6 to Level 7. This change is necessary for 1 year (202526), ahead of the role out of the new BIOS modules.

Will appear in programme F1BF - Medicinal Chemistry with Pharmacology MChem. DEPP forms detailing changes to the programme have been submitted to School of Physical Sciences. This will appear in CM in due course.

Overview

Overview
This module will be delivered by a series of lectures and tutorials to provide an up-to-date understanding of CNS conditions, drugs that are used to treat those conditions, and how CNS drugs work at the cellular and molecular level.

The module will be delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Students will critically evaluate scientific literature and clinical data, synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex problems by applying appropriate knowledge, skills and creative thinking.

The module will be assessed by two summative exercises including data interpretation and analysis.
The prerequisite module is LIFE207 Principles of Pharmacology .
Educational Aims
To provide an explanation of the current understanding of drug treatment for common disorders of the brain.

To explain the latest knowledge of the pathophysiology of the brain, receptors and ion channels as drug targets, and the mechanisms of action of key classes of neuropharmacological agents.

To give students an awareness of the clinical effectiveness of neuropharmacological drugs.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The aim of this module is to provide an understanding of of drug treatment for common disorders of the brain. A further aim is to explain the molecular mechanism of action of key classes of neuropharmacological agents and the potential for side-effects and drug toxicity. Materials will be delivered through a series of lectures and tutorials. The module will be delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Students will critically evaluate scientific literature and clinical data, synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex problems by applying appropriate knowledge and skills. Problem solving, critical thinking, creativity will be utilised in analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions. The module will be assessed by two summative exercise. The module would be taken by students with a keen interest in neuropharmacology and medicinal chemistry.
Outline Syllabus
Lectures will split into three blocks and themed around neurotransmission in the nervous system, focusing on glutamate and GABA as neurotransmitters, treatments for depression, anxiety etc.   G-protein coupled receptors, structure activity relationships, their role in adrenergic neurotransmission.   Epilepsy, antiepileptic drug development, pharmacology of antiepileptic drugs.

Block, lecture title and theme:

Block 1: Drug targets at the synapse
Overview of neurotransmission in the CNS
Block 1: Drug targets at the synapse
Transporters at the synapse
Block 1: Drug targets at the synapse
Inhibitory neurotransmission; focus on GABAA receptor
Block 1: Drug targets at the synapse
Targets for the development of novel anti-depressants

Block 2: GPCRs
G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) systems
Block 2: GPCRs
Adrenoceptors: structure and function
Block 2: GPCRs
GPCR receptor theory and second messengers GPCRs
Block 2: GPCRs
GPCR diversification and desensitization

Block 3: Epilepsy
Epilepsy: clinical features and basic mechanisms
Block 3: Epilepsy
Pharmacology of traditional anti-epileptic drugs
Block 3: Epilepsy
Pharmacology of new anti-epileptic drugs
Block 3: Epilepsy
Alternative pharmacological and non-pharmacological treatments

This builds on the broader content covered in LIFE207 around understanding of the quantitative aspects of drug action, the relationship between drug efficacy and chemical structure, pharmacokinetics, drug concentration and response.

Library resources will be accessible through the module reading list, other key learning resources will accessible through VLE, Canvas. All journal articles are either Open Access or available as PDF's through Canvas.

Students are provided with reading material ahead of the lectures and are expected to read all resources on the reading list in order to complete the assessments and tutorials. Supplementary resources are encouraged for the assessments. Pre-tutorial material will be released in order to help them complete the tutorial.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching and learning method 1: Synchronous F2F lectures (13 x 1 hr lectures) to include polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc.

Teaching and learning method 2: Online asynchronous tutorial (2 x 1 hr) - These will take place at suitable points after delivery of the relevant F2F material and before the relevant assessments.

Teaching and learning method 3 (60 hrs): Self-directed learning aided by directed reading and formative questions on neuropharmacology. A list of reading material, from scientific papers to book chapters, will be provided for students at the end of each lecture to support their learning and progression through the course.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework: This module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students access the core attributes and hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. For example:

-Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. Students will receive formative feedback, both verbally and written, through the formative tutorials.

-Research-connected teaching: inclusion of clinical case studies allows incorporation of relevant, recent research. The module is delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence.

-Active learning: All lecture sessions aim to incorporate some element of active learning through short periods of tutor-led discussion, peer discussion, problem solving, polling etc.

-Confidence: students will learn to be able to adapt and apply their knowledge in new contexts through tutorial-based activities.
-Digital fluency: throughput the module students will think critically about the information they find and use, developing their ability to use digital platforms to problem-solve, create, collaborate, and communicate.

- Global citizenship: the module increases awareness of global disease burden and global drug development initiatives and students' potential future roles within these areas.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students will interpret scientific data and complete a written assessment that combines problem solving with synthesis of research-led materials.

Assessment cycle-I will be a 1000 word written assignment that involves data interpretation/essay focused on Drug targets at the synapse and GPCR's. This will be worth 40% and occur following the first cycle of teaching in week 6 to 8.

Assessment cycle-II will be a 1500 word written assignment that involves data interpretation/essay focused on Epilepsy. This will be worth 60% and occur at the end of the course in week 11 to 13 in May.

Feedback from Cycle 1 is received within 3 weeks so relevant feedback on structure, referencing and formatting etc can be applied to Cycle 2. Detailed feedback is released through Speedgrader on Canvas.

Reassessment strategy: there is a resit opportunity. The format of the assessments will be very similar but different questions will be employed. This will take place in the normal reassessment window and be capped at 50%. The resit in the summer covers both cycle I and cycle II. Failure of cycle I assessment does not impact ability to sit the cycle II assessment as different content is involved. The standard CoPA penalty for late submission applies.

Assessment is anonymous and submitted through Canvas the VLE which allows anonymous submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Prior LIFE modules in earlier years prepare students for the submissions therefore no draft opportunity is given, as is standard through all LIFE cycled assessments. Following assessment release they have 1 week to ask any questions relating to the assessment.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Critically evaluate and explain the central role of excitatory and inhibitory neurotransmission in the nervous system in health and disease​
 LO2 ​Identify major classes of drug targets in the nervous system and critically evaluate how those targets interact with intracellular effector mechanisms​
 LO3 ​Critically appraise and analyse the characteristic features of epilepsy, the range of drugs available for its treatment, and how those drugs interact with specific targets in the brain
Skills

Skills

 S3 Analysis of facts and situations.
 S4 Self-directed and independent learning.

Unable to delete old rational above.

This module is due to commence September 2025.

Due to Chemistry curriculum changes LIFE369 (taken exclusively by Year 4 Integrated MChem Medicinal Chemistry students) is now required to be Level 7 to ensure the students have the correct number of Level 7 credits in Year 4. LO's and subsequent assessment marking rubrics have been altered to reflect the change from Level 6 to Level 7. This change is necessary for 1 year (202526), ahead of the role out of the new BIOS modules.

Will appear in programme F1BF - Medicinal Chemistry with Pharmacology MChem. DEPP forms detailing changes to the programme have been submitted to School of Physical Sciences. This will appear in CM in due course.

Overview

Overview
This module will be delivered by a series of lectures and tutorials to provide an up-to-date understanding of CNS conditions, drugs that are used to treat those conditions, and how CNS drugs work at the cellular and molecular level.

The module will be delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Students will critically evaluate scientific literature and clinical data, synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex problems by applying appropriate knowledge, skills and creative thinking.

The module will be assessed by two summative exercises including data interpretation and analysis.
The prerequisite module is LIFE207 Principles of Pharmacology .
Educational Aims
To provide an explanation of the current understanding of drug treatment for common disorders of the brain.

To explain the latest knowledge of the pathophysiology of the brain, receptors and ion channels as drug targets, and the mechanisms of action of key classes of neuropharmacological agents.

To give students an awareness of the clinical effectiveness of neuropharmacological drugs.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The aim of this module is to provide an understanding of of drug treatment for common disorders of the brain. A further aim is to explain the molecular mechanism of action of key classes of neuropharmacological agents and the potential for side-effects and drug toxicity. Materials will be delivered through a series of lectures and tutorials. The module will be delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Students will critically evaluate scientific literature and clinical data, synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex problems by applying appropriate knowledge and skills. Problem solving, critical thinking, creativity will be utilised in analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions. The module will be assessed by two summative exercise. The module would be taken by students with a keen interest in neuropharmacology and medicinal chemistry.
Outline Syllabus
Lectures will split into three blocks and themed around neurotransmission in the nervous system, focusing on glutamate and GABA as neurotransmitters, treatments for depression, anxiety etc.   G-protein coupled receptors, structure activity relationships, their role in adrenergic neurotransmission.   Epilepsy, antiepileptic drug development, pharmacology of antiepileptic drugs.

Block, lecture title and theme:

Block 1: Drug targets at the synapse
Overview of neurotransmission in the CNS
Block 1: Drug targets at the synapse
Transporters at the synapse
Block 1: Drug targets at the synapse
Inhibitory neurotransmission; focus on GABAA receptor
Block 1: Drug targets at the synapse
Targets for the development of novel anti-depressants

Block 2: GPCRs
G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) systems
Block 2: GPCRs
Adrenoceptors: structure and function
Block 2: GPCRs
GPCR receptor theory and second messengers GPCRs
Block 2: GPCRs
GPCR diversification and desensitization

Block 3: Epilepsy
Epilepsy: clinical features and basic mechanisms
Block 3: Epilepsy
Pharmacology of traditional anti-epileptic drugs
Block 3: Epilepsy
Pharmacology of new anti-epileptic drugs
Block 3: Epilepsy
Alternative pharmacological and non-pharmacological treatments

This builds on the broader content covered in LIFE207 around understanding of the quantitative aspects of drug action, the relationship between drug efficacy and chemical structure, pharmacokinetics, drug concentration and response.

Library resources will be accessible through the module reading list, other key learning resources will accessible through VLE, Canvas. All journal articles are either Open Access or available as PDF's through Canvas.

Students are provided with reading material ahead of the lectures and are expected to read all resources on the reading list in order to complete the assessments and tutorials. Supplementary resources are encouraged for the assessments. Pre-tutorial material will be released in order to help them complete the tutorial.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching and learning method 1: Synchronous F2F lectures (13 x 1 hr lectures) to include polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc.

Teaching and learning method 2: Online asynchronous tutorial (2 x 1 hr) - These will take place at suitable points after delivery of the relevant F2F material and before the relevant assessments.

Teaching and learning method 3 (60 hrs): Self-directed learning aided by directed reading and formative questions on neuropharmacology. A list of reading material, from scientific papers to book chapters, will be provided for students at the end of each lecture to support their learning and progression through the course.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework: This module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students access the core attributes and hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. For example:

-Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. Students will receive formative feedback, both verbally and written, through the formative tutorials.

-Research-connected teaching: inclusion of clinical case studies allows incorporation of relevant, recent research. The module is delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence.

-Active learning: All lecture sessions aim to incorporate some element of active learning through short periods of tutor-led discussion, peer discussion, problem solving, polling etc.

-Confidence: students will learn to be able to adapt and apply their knowledge in new contexts through tutorial-based activities.
-Digital fluency: throughput the module students will think critically about the information they find and use, developing their ability to use digital platforms to problem-solve, create, collaborate, and communicate.

- Global citizenship: the module increases awareness of global disease burden and global drug development initiatives and students' potential future roles within these areas.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students will interpret scientific data and complete a written assessment that combines problem solving with synthesis of research-led materials.

Assessment cycle-I will be a 1000 word written assignment that involves data interpretation/essay focused on Drug targets at the synapse and GPCR's. This will be worth 40% and occur following the first cycle of teaching in week 6 to 8.

Assessment cycle-II will be a 1500 word written assignment that involves data interpretation/essay focused on Epilepsy. This will be worth 60% and occur at the end of the course in week 11 to 13 in May.

Feedback from Cycle 1 is received within 3 weeks so relevant feedback on structure, referencing and formatting etc can be applied to Cycle 2. Detailed feedback is released through Speedgrader on Canvas.

Reassessment strategy: there is a resit opportunity. The format of the assessments will be very similar but different questions will be employed. This will take place in the normal reassessment window and be capped at 50%. The resit in the summer covers both cycle I and cycle II. Failure of cycle I assessment does not impact ability to sit the cycle II assessment as different content is involved. The standard CoPA penalty for late submission applies.

Assessment is anonymous and submitted through Canvas the VLE which allows anonymous submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Prior LIFE modules in earlier years prepare students for the submissions therefore no draft opportunity is given, as is standard through all LIFE cycled assessments. Following assessment release they have 1 week to ask any questions relating to the assessment.

Notes
Unable to delete old rational above.

This module is due to commence September 2025.

Due to Chemistry curriculum changes LIFE369 (taken exclusively by Year 4 Integrated MChem Medicinal Chemistry students) is now required to be Level 7 to ensure the students have the correct number of Level 7 credits in Year 4. LO's and subsequent assessment marking rubrics have been altered to reflect the change from Level 6 to Level 7. This change is necessary for 1 year (202526), ahead of the role out of the new BIOS modules.

Will appear in programme F1BF - Medicinal Chemistry with Pharmacology MChem. DEPP forms detailing changes to the programme have been submitted to School of Physical Sciences. This will appear in CM in due course.

Overview

Overview
This module will be delivered by a series of lectures and tutorials to provide an up-to-date understanding of CNS conditions, drugs that are used to treat those conditions, and how CNS drugs work at the cellular and molecular level.

The module will be delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Students will critically evaluate scientific literature and clinical data, synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex problems by applying appropriate knowledge, skills and creative thinking.

The module will be assessed by two summative exercises including data interpretation and analysis.
The prerequisite module is LIFE207 Principles of Pharmacology .
Educational Aims
To provide an explanation of the current understanding of drug treatment for common disorders of the brain.

To explain the latest knowledge of the pathophysiology of the brain, receptors and ion channels as drug targets, and the mechanisms of action of key classes of neuropharmacological agents.

To give students an awareness of the clinical effectiveness of neuropharmacological drugs.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The aim of this module is to provide an understanding of of drug treatment for common disorders of the brain. A further aim is to explain the molecular mechanism of action of key classes of neuropharmacological agents and the potential for side-effects and drug toxicity. Materials will be delivered through a series of lectures and tutorials. The module will be delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Students will critically evaluate scientific literature and clinical data, synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex problems by applying appropriate knowledge and skills. Problem solving, critical thinking, creativity will be utilised in analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions. The module will be assessed by two summative exercise. The module would be taken by students with a keen interest in neuropharmacology and medicinal chemistry.
Outline Syllabus
Lectures will split into three blocks and themed around neurotransmission in the nervous system, focusing on glutamate and GABA as neurotransmitters, treatments for depression, anxiety etc.   G-protein coupled receptors, structure activity relationships, their role in adrenergic neurotransmission.   Epilepsy, antiepileptic drug development, pharmacology of antiepileptic drugs.

Block, lecture title and theme:

Block 1: Drug targets at the synapse
Overview of neurotransmission in the CNS
Block 1: Drug targets at the synapse
Transporters at the synapse
Block 1: Drug targets at the synapse
Inhibitory neurotransmission; focus on GABAA receptor
Block 1: Drug targets at the synapse
Targets for the development of novel anti-depressants

Block 2: GPCRs
G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) systems
Block 2: GPCRs
Adrenoceptors: structure and function
Block 2: GPCRs
GPCR receptor theory and second messengers GPCRs
Block 2: GPCRs
GPCR diversification and desensitization

Block 3: Epilepsy
Epilepsy: clinical features and basic mechanisms
Block 3: Epilepsy
Pharmacology of traditional anti-epileptic drugs
Block 3: Epilepsy
Pharmacology of new anti-epileptic drugs
Block 3: Epilepsy
Alternative pharmacological and non-pharmacological treatments

This builds on the broader content covered in LIFE207 around understanding of the quantitative aspects of drug action, the relationship between drug efficacy and chemical structure, pharmacokinetics, drug concentration and response.

Library resources will be accessible through the module reading list, other key learning resources will accessible through VLE, Canvas. All journal articles are either Open Access or available as PDF's through Canvas.

Students are provided with reading material ahead of the lectures and are expected to read all resources on the reading list in order to complete the assessments and tutorials. Supplementary resources are encouraged for the assessments. Pre-tutorial material will be released in order to help them complete the tutorial.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching and learning method 1: Synchronous F2F lectures (13 x 1 hr lectures) to include polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc.

Teaching and learning method 2: Online asynchronous tutorial (2 x 1 hr) - These will take place at suitable points after delivery of the relevant F2F material and before the relevant assessments.

Teaching and learning method 3 (60 hrs): Self-directed learning aided by directed reading and formative questions on neuropharmacology. A list of reading material, from scientific papers to book chapters, will be provided for students at the end of each lecture to support their learning and progression through the course.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework: This module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students access the core attributes and hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. For example:

-Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. Students will receive formative feedback, both verbally and written, through the formative tutorials.

-Research-connected teaching: inclusion of clinical case studies allows incorporation of relevant, recent research. The module is delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence.

-Active learning: All lecture sessions aim to incorporate some element of active learning through short periods of tutor-led discussion, peer discussion, problem solving, polling etc.

-Confidence: students will learn to be able to adapt and apply their knowledge in new contexts through tutorial-based activities.
-Digital fluency: throughput the module students will think critically about the information they find and use, developing their ability to use digital platforms to problem-solve, create, collaborate, and communicate.

- Global citizenship: the module increases awareness of global disease burden and global drug development initiatives and students' potential future roles within these areas.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students will interpret scientific data and complete a written assessment that combines problem solving with synthesis of research-led materials.

Assessment cycle-I will be a 1000 word written assignment that involves data interpretation/essay focused on Drug targets at the synapse and GPCR's. This will be worth 40% and occur following the first cycle of teaching in week 6 to 8.

Assessment cycle-II will be a 1500 word written assignment that involves data interpretation/essay focused on Epilepsy. This will be worth 60% and occur at the end of the course in week 11 to 13 in May.

Feedback from Cycle 1 is received within 3 weeks so relevant feedback on structure, referencing and formatting etc can be applied to Cycle 2. Detailed feedback is released through Speedgrader on Canvas.

Reassessment strategy: there is a resit opportunity. The format of the assessments will be very similar but different questions will be employed. This will take place in the normal reassessment window and be capped at 50%. The resit in the summer covers both cycle I and cycle II. Failure of cycle I assessment does not impact ability to sit the cycle II assessment as different content is involved. The standard CoPA penalty for late submission applies.

Assessment is anonymous and submitted through Canvas the VLE which allows anonymous submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Prior LIFE modules in earlier years prepare students for the submissions therefore no draft opportunity is given, as is standard through all LIFE cycled assessments. Following assessment release they have 1 week to ask any questions relating to the assessment.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Critically evaluate and explain the central role of excitatory and inhibitory neurotransmission in the nervous system in health and disease​
 LO2 ​Identify major classes of drug targets in the nervous system and critically evaluate how those targets interact with intracellular effector mechanisms​
 LO3 ​Critically appraise and analyse the characteristic features of epilepsy, the range of drugs available for its treatment, and how those drugs interact with specific targets in the brain
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 ​Ability to produce clear, structured written work and oral literacy - including listening and questioning.
 S2 ​Problem solving and critical thinking
 S3 Analysis of facts and situations.
 S4 Self-directed and independent learning.
